title: 109_s1968
content: The Court Security Improvement Act of 2005 establishes security requirements for the judicial branch and mandates consultation between the Director of the United States Marshals Service and the Judicial Conference. It also addresses the protection of family members. SEC. 3 amends the Ethics in Government Act to protect family members. SEC. 4 extends the sunset provision to 2009. SEC. 5 provides protections against malicious recording of fictitious liens against federal judges and law enforcement officers. Sec. 1521 of Chapter 73 of title 18, United States Code, imposes penalties for filing false liens or encumbrances against Federal judges or law enforcement officers. Offenders can be fined or imprisoned for up to 10 years for knowingly submitting fraudulent claims. The term "Federal judge" includes various types of judges in the United States, while "Federal law enforcement officer" is defined in section 115 of the title. The chapter analysis for chapter 73 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding a new item. SEC. 1521 prohibits retaliating against a Federal judge or law enforcement officer through false claims or slander of title. The new law prohibits making restricted personal information about a covered official publicly available with the intent to harm them, punishable by fines and imprisonment up to 5 years. The new law defines restricted personal information as details like home address, phone numbers, and email, pertaining to covered officials such as judges, law enforcement officers, jurors, and their immediate family members. The chapter analysis for chapter 7 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding a new item. SEC. 7 prohibits possession of dangerous weapons in federal court facilities, amending Section 930(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 8 clarifies venue for retaliation against a witness under Section 1513. SEC. 9 establishes a Witness Protection Grant Program under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. "Part II - Witness Protection Grants authorized under SEC. 2995." "Grants may be awarded to States, local governments, and Indian tribes to establish or expand witness protection programs to safeguard victims and witnesses from threats and intimidation. Funds must be used for this purpose, with priority given to jurisdictions with the greatest need for such programs and serious violent crime issues." Authorization of Appropriations: $20,000,000 for each fiscal year 2006 through 2010 to establish or expand witness protection programs in jurisdictions with serious violent crime problems and instances of threats and intimidation against victims and witnesses. SEC. 10 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 authorizes grants to states for creating and expanding witness and victim protection programs to prevent threats and intimidation against victims and witnesses of violent crimes. An authorization of $20,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2010 is provided to carry out this program. SEC. 11. ELIGIBILITY OF STATE COURTS FOR CERTAIN FEDERAL GRANTS. State courts are now eligible for grants to improve security under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. Priority will be given to State court applicants with the greatest need for security enhancements. State courts eligible for grants under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 will have priority based on demonstrated need for security enhancements. Amendments allocate 70% for security, 10% for other purposes, and 10% for specific security needs. The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims is amended by replacing "district courts" with "Courts of Appeals." Additionally, there are amendments related to life insurance for bankruptcy, magistrate, and territorial judges. The text discusses amendments related to bankruptcy judges and United States magistrate judges for the purpose of construing and applying chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code. Amendments are made regarding territorial judges in Guam and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands for the purpose of applying chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code. Amendments are made for territorial judges in the Virgin Islands to apply chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code. The appointment of judges in the Virgin Islands for insurance rate regulation includes judges under section 373 of title 28, United States Code, who are considered judges of the United States under section 8701(a)(5) of title 5. SEC. 14. Health insurance provided for surviving family and spouses of judges. Section 8901(3) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include a member of a family who is a survivor of various types of judges and justices. Section 8901(3) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include a member of a family who is a survivor of judges or justices, including a United States bankruptcy judge or a full-time United States magistrate judge.
